seg.seg: ... sitting on the splendid royal throne with (ornaments (?)), (surrounded by) the kings, the ministers [and] the (people) of the country, ...
... with a tongue of lotus colour, with a charming voice, (with) confident [and] reliable firm(ness) proper to a Bodhisattva ...
teaching to the people of the country the Law starting with himself, he says:
« ... having left. After having destroyed the existence of a woman, having become a man, attaining the status of kingship [afterwards],
... having (under)stood ..., put (pl.) treasures with gifts among the begging ones! (1.) Among the people receiving [gifts]
... place (pl.) joyfulness in the ones provided with ...! Because if these ones (with the power (?)) of virtue
... having become the most advantageous of the giving beings, [even] more [so] than (father and mo)ther, precisely in this birth ...
... (they) give merits [that] give fruits of happiness without number nor count.
... And in addition [listen to the following]: In [the tune] wärṣin: «The begging one says [words of] praise, the giving one (makes the people) ama(zed) (?) ...
... this one (should not be) scorned; the begging one gives renown [and] merits, by giving something [lit. a thing] ... (1.)».
... In that way this Bodhisattva [named] Rupyāvata (sic!) as a king during sixty years (held) the kingship,
... ornated by virtues without number, having passed from this earth, (he was reborn in) the world of the Tuṣita gods.

p.note: -syo is the end of an instr. pl., probably (yetwe)syo 'with ornaments'.
For the meaning of the adverb/uninflected adjective ṣārce, see b 5.
The meter has most probably 4x15 (7/8) syllables, according to Siegling, pers. copy.

The passage refers to the first and second births of the Bodhisattva: he started as a woman named Rūpāvatī who gave up her life in order to feed a starving woman and renounced her female sex becoming a man afterwards; the Bodhisattva was then reborn as a prince named Rūpāvata. This story culminates in a5 in a prompt to be as generous as these previous beings.

Since the sign ‹ṣä› is on the same level as the following akṣaras of the line and since there is no trace of virāma, we prefer to read ṣäṃ. we- has to belong to a disyllabic form because of the meter, a probable restoration would be we(yeṃ) 'wonderful, amazed'.
